Current status and future predicted distribution patterns of bilharzia transmitting snails and implications for vector-borne diseases in South Africa
Project
• Address the lack in knowledge regarding the present distribution of schistosomiasis in South Africa using a combined field and desktop based study approach. • Determine whether the ranges of schistosomiasis intermediate host snails and their associated parasites have expanded or changed in the past half century • Assess existing knowledge, attitudes, perceptions and practices surrounding schistosomiasis in endemic communities • Investigate whether changes may further expand and increase the potential prevalence of the disease in humans and animals given future predicted climate change.
View
Diversity of the Diplostomidae (Digenea: Diplostomoidea) from Tilapia sparrmanii in the North-West Province, South Africa
Archived project
The aim of the study is to identify the diversity of trematodes belonging to the family Diplostomidae in the Banded tilapia, T. sparrmanii in the North-West Province. Objectives: 1. To examine fish from the three localities for the presence of the parasites belonging to the family Diplostomidae. 2. To provide accurate morphological description of the found diplostomid trematodes. 3. To generate sequence data, partial mitochondrial (cox1) and nuclear (28S) genes, and internal transcribed spacer region (ITS1-5.8S-ITS2) for isolates obtained from T. sparrmanii. 4. To conduct phylogenetic analyses for species identification to the lowest possible taxonomic level. 5. To gather data on the water quality and sediment size and organic contents from the three localities.
